tha10:527: "The trees are now crimson, venerable sir,They’ve shed their foliage, and are ready to fruit.They’re splendid, as if on fire;Great hero, this period is full of flavour.
tha10:528: The blossoming trees are delightful,Wafting their scent all around, in all directions,They’ve shed their leaves and wish to fruit,Hero, it is time to depart from here.
tha10:529: It is neither too hot nor too cold,Venerable sir, it’s a pleasant season for travelling.Let the Sākiyas and Koḷiyas see you,Facing west as you cross the Rohiṇī river.
tha10:530: In hope, the field is ploughed;The seed is sown in hope;In hope, merchants travel the seas,Carrying rich cargoes.The hope that I stand for:May it succeed!
tha10:531: Again and again, they sow the seed;Again and again, the king of gods sends rain;Again and again, farmers plough the field;Again and again, grain is produced for the nation.
tha10:532: Again and again, the beggars wander,Again and again, the donors give,Again and again, when the donors have given,Again and again, they go to their place in heaven.
tha10:533: A hero of vast wisdom purifies seven generationsOf the family in which they’re born.Sakya, I believe you’re the king of kings,Since you fathered the one who is truly called a sage.
tha10:534: The father of the great sage is named Suddhodana;But the Buddha’s mother is named Māyā.Having borne the Bodhisatta in her womb,She rejoices in the heaven of the Thirty-Three.
tha10:535: When she died and passed away from here,She was blessed with divine sensual pleasures;Rejoicing in the five kinds of sensual pleasures,Gotamī is surrounded by those hosts of gods."
tha10:536: "I’m the son of the Buddha, the incomparable Angīrasa, the poised —I bear the unbearable.You, Sakya, are my father’s father;Gotama, you are my grandfather in the Dhamma."
tha10:537: If no-one else is foundIn front or behind,It’s extremely pleasant,Dwelling alone in a forest grove.
tha10:538: Come now, I’ll go aloneTo the wilderness praised by the Buddha.It’s pleasant for a monkDwelling alone and resolute.
tha10:539: Alone and self-disciplined,I’ll quickly enter the delightful forest,Which gives joy to meditators,And is frequented by rutting elephants.
tha10:540: In Sītavana, so full of flowers,In a cool mountain cave,I’ll bathe my limbsAnd walk meditation alone.
tha10:541: When will I dwell alone,Without a companion,In the great wood, so delightful,My task complete, free of defilements?
tha10:542: This is what I want to do:May my wish succeed!I’ll make it happen myself:No-one can do someone else’s duty.
tha10:543: Fastening my armour,I’ll enter the forest.I won’t leave hereUntil I have attained the end of defilements.
tha10:544: As the cool breeze blowsWith fragrant scent,I’ll split ignorance apart,Sitting on the mountain-peak.
tha10:545: In a forest grove covered with blossoms,In a cave so very cool,I take pleasure in Giribbaja,Happy with the happiness of freedom.
tha10:546: My intentions are fulfilledLike the moon on the fifteenth day.With the utter ending of all defilements,Now there is no more rebirth into any state of existence.
tha10:547: If you’re prepared for the future,Both the good and the bad,Then those who look for your weakness,Whether enemies or well-wishers, will find none.
tha10:548: One who has fulfilled, developed,And gradually consolidatedMindfulness of breathingAs taught by the Buddha:They light up the world,Like the moon freed from a cloud.
tha10:549: Yes, my mind is clean,Measureless, and well-developed;It is broken through and uplifted —It radiates in every direction.
tha10:550: The wise person lives onEven after loss of wealth;But without gaining wisdomEven a rich person doesn’t really live.
tha10:551: Understanding questions what is learned;Understanding grows fame and reputation;A person who has understandingFinds happiness even among sufferings.
tha10:552: It’s not something just for today;It isn’t incredible or astonishing.When you’re born, you die —What’s astonishing about that?
tha10:553: For anyone who is born,Death always follows after living.Everyone who is born here dies here;Such is the nature of living beings.
tha10:554: The things that are useful for the livingAre of no use for the dead —Not fame, not celebrity,Not praise by ascetics and brahmins;For the dead, there is only weeping.
tha10:555: And weeping impairs the eye and the body;Complexion, health, and intelligence decline.Your enemies rejoice;But your well-wishers are not happy.
tha10:556: So you should wish that those who stay in your familyHave understanding and learning,And do their duty though the power of understanding,Just as you’d cross a full river by boat.
tha10:557: My progress was slow,I was despised in the past;My brother turned me away,Saying, "Go home now".
tha10:558: Turned away at the gateOf the Saṅgha’s monastery,I stood there sadly,Longing for the teaching.
tha10:559: Then Blessed One cameAnd touched my head.Taking me by the arm,He brought me into the Saṅgha’s monastery.
tha10:560: The teacher, out of compassion,Gave me a foot-wiping cloth, saying:"Focus your awarenessExclusively on this clean cloth."
tha10:561: After I had listened to his words,I dwelt delighting in his teaching,PractisingsamādhiFor the attainment of the highest goal.
tha10:562: I know my past life;My divine eye is clarified;I’ve attained the three knowledges,And fulfilled the Buddha’s instructions.
tha10:563: I, Panthaka, created a thousandImages of myself,And sat in the delightful mango groveUntil the time for the meal offering was announced.
tha10:564: Then the teacher sent to meA messenger to announce the time.When the time was announced,I flew to him through the air.
tha10:565: I paid homage to the teacher’s feet,And sat to one side.When he knew I was seated,The teacher received the offering.
tha10:566: Recipient of gifts from the whole world,Receiver of sacrifices,Field of merit for humanity,He received the offering.
tha10:567: Filled with different kinds of dirt,A great producer of dung,Like a stagnant cesspool,A great boil, a great wound,
tha10:568: Full of pus and blood,Sunk in a toilet-pit,Trickling with fluidsThis putrid body always oozes.
tha10:569: Bound by sixty tendons,Coated with a fleshy coating,Clothed in a jacket of skin,This putrid body is worthless.
tha10:570: Held together by a skeleton of bones,And bound by sinews;It assumes posturesDue to a complex of many things.
tha10:571: We set out in the certainty of death,In the presence of the king of death;And having discarded the body right here,A person goes where he likes.
tha10:572: Enveloped by ignorance,Tied by the four ties,This body is sinking in the flood,Caught in the net of underlying tendencies.
tha10:573: Yoked with the five hindrances,Afflicted by thought,Accompanied by the root of craving,Hidden by delusion.
tha10:574: So the body goes on,Propelled by the mechanism of deeds.But existence ends in perishing;Separated, the body perishes.
tha10:575: Those blind, unawakened peopleWho think of this body as theirs,Swell the horrors of the charnel-ground,And take up rebirth again in some state of existence.
tha10:576: Those who avoid this body,Like a snake smeared with dung,They expel the root of rebirth,And realisenibbāna, without defilements.
tha10:577: In order to go on retreat,A monk should stay in lodgingsThat are secluded and quiet,Frequented by beasts of prey.
tha10:578: Having gathered scraps from rubbish heaps,Cemeteries and streets,And making an outer robe from them,He should wear that coarse robe.
tha10:579: Humbling his mind,A monk should walk for almsFrom family to family without exception,With sense doors guarded, well-restrained .
tha10:580: He should be content even with coarse food,Not hoping for lots of flavours.The mind that is greedy for flavoursDoesn’t delight injhāna.
tha10:581: With few wishes, content,A sage should live secluded.Socializing with neitherHouseholders nor the homeless.
tha10:582: He should appearTo be stupid or dumb;A wise person would not speak overly longIn the midst of the Saṅgha.
tha10:583: He would not insult anyone,And would avoid causing harm.Restrained in accordance with the Pāṭimokkha,He would eat in moderation.
tha10:584: Skilled in the arising of thought,He would grasp well the character of the mind.He would be devoted to practicingSerenity and insight at the right time.
tha10:585: Though endowed with energy and perseverance,And always devoted to meditation,A wise person would not be too sure of themselves,Until they have attained the end of suffering.
tha10:586: For a monk who dwells in this way,Longing for purification,All his defilements wither away,And he attainsnibbāna.
tha10:587: You should understand your own purpose,And consider the teachings carefully,As well as what’s appropriate,For one who has entered the ascetic life.
tha10:588: Good friendship in the community,Undertaking lots of training,Listening well to the teacher —This is appropriate for an ascetic.
tha10:589: Respect for the Buddha,Reverence for the Dhamma as it really is,Esteem for the Saṅgha —This is appropriate for an ascetic.
tha10:590: Devotion to good conduct and resort,A livelihood that is pure and blameless,And settling the mind —This is appropriate for an ascetic.
tha10:591: A pleasing manner in things that should be done,And those that should be avoided;Devotion to the higher mind —This is appropriate for an ascetic.
tha10:592: Wilderness lodgingsRemote, with little noise,Fit for use by a sage —This is appropriate for an ascetic.
tha10:593: Ethics, learning,Investigation of Dhamma as it really is,And penetration of the truths —This is appropriate for an ascetic.
tha10:594: Developing the perceptionsOf impermanence, non-self, and unattractiveness,And displeasure with the whole world —This is appropriate for an ascetic.
tha10:595: Developing the factors of awakening,The bases for psychic power, the spiritual faculties and powers,And the noble eight-fold path —This is appropriate for an ascetic.
tha10:596: A sage should abandon craving,With defilements split apart, root and all,They should live liberated —This is appropriate for an ascetic.
